conclusion: The two objects will meet at the instant when the areas under their two velocity-time curves become equal.
Object A travels first with a velocity that decreases from v₀ to 0 over t₁, then its velocity rises linearly to v₀ again at t₂.
Object B is at rest until t₂, after which its velocity increases (concave up) from 0 to v₀, reaching v₀ at t₄.

premise: Displacement of A from 0 to t₁ is the area of the left shaded curve.
conclusion: Displacement of A from 0 to t₁ is calculated as the area under the curve from 0 to t₁.

premise: From t₁ to t₂, A’s displacement is the area of the triangle under the straight-line rise.
conclusion: Displacement of A from t₁ to t₂ is calculated as the area of the triangle under the straight-line rise.

premise: Displacement of B from t₂ to t₄ is the area under its rising curve.
conclusion: Displacement of B from t₂ to t₄ is calculated as the area under its rising curve.

premise: Because the total area under A’s curve from 0 → t₂ equals the total area under B’s curve from t₂ → t₄.
conclusion: The total displacement of A from 0 to t₂ equals the total displacement of B from t₂ to t₄.

premise: The two shaded regions are equal exactly at the time t₃ where the two curves intersect.
conclusion: The two objects meet at t = t₃.
